column6: I'm an intended Economics and Math double major, but have never taken a Statistics class in my life! This summer, I worked as a research assistant at the UC Berkeley School of Public Health, where I supported the development of a novel dataset tracking physician merger and acquisition activity, then analyzed healthcare consolidation impacts on Medicare/Medicaid care quality. During the summer, I taught myself some fundamentals of data analysis and programming in R out of necessity. That said, the experience definitely highlighted how much I would benefit from a more formal Statistics education, given my strong interest in public health economics.
column7: In my aforementioned work at Berkeley this summer, I was attempting to model the amount of physician M&A activity in each month of the year. I noticed our data showed that materially more M&A activity was occurring in January than in other months. However, when I dug into this finding, I realized we were defaulting to listing 1/1/#### as the acquisition date for all private equity acquisitions for which the press release did not provide a precise date. When I brought this up to my supervisor, we ended up creating a flag feature in our dataset for these ambiguous cases, which helped us avoid the conclusion that private equity firms really like to make acquisitions during the middle of winter :). This moment, as well as countless other moments from this summer, showed me the value of PRECISION and careful consideration of nitty gritty details.
column8: I'm interested in datasets related to public health, specifically in the SF Bay Area (where I'm from!). I'm also curious about datasets regarding student-athletes at Williams and outdoor recreation in Williamstown.

column7: I'm participating in a Fantasy Football league with some of my mates from back home, and oftentimes, statistics plays an important role for the lesser injury-prone positions, where longevity and consistency become a more important factor for success. Quarterbacks, for example, only really experience minor injuries during rushes or sacks, so identifying a QB with minimal spread across week-to-week performances might make him a better starting choice over someone else with higher spread. At the same time, when you draft for your bench players, the opposite might be true (depending on your strategy), as a player with volatile upside can land you an occasional fairy run that might boost your points for the week.

column7: A recent time that I saw statistics used in the real world was in a research project that I was involved in over the summer! My project revolved around a cohort of 13 post-cardiac arrest patients who were selected to receive an ICP monitor to help inform their treatment. The goal of the project was to characterize the clinical characteristics and experiences of each of these patients! In doing so, we began to parse out which specific symptoms and biomarkers presented with statistical significance for abnormalities throughout the entirety of the cohort. This allowed us to try to more selectively and accurately define clinical criteria that would indicate which patients would benefit the most from this new treatment!

column7: Recently, my friend Rex and I were talking about the massive Powerball jackpot that has climbed to around $1.7 billion. He joked that this might be the "best" time to buy a ticket statistically, since the prize was so high compared to the odds. But, the odds of a player selecting all six numbers are 1 in 292.2 million. Maybe he meant winning any prize, which is just 1 in 24.9. Overall, what caught my attention was the way that he talked about probability without understanding all the factors. This reminded me of our discussion in class the other day about the difficulty of making inferences with confounding variables.

column7: One moment that stands out to me the most is from my first year on the field hockey team at Williams. One of the seniors on the team, who I got pretty close with by the end of the year because our coach made us "buddies," was a stats major at Williams and she would always use her stats knowledge to try to predict the outcomes of games and how final brackets would work out between the teams in our league ahead of time. We didn't rely on her or expect her to get the right answer every time, but it was both fun and fascinating to watch her be able to apply what she was doing in the classroom to a real world example and another part of her life. I was interested by this example because it made me realize more clearly that the things we are learning every day actually do apply to the real world, and I am excited to start learning some of the statistics she was using to predict our season outcomes!
column8: I don't really know anything about datasets (and honestly what you mean by what types of datasets) but I like the idea of learning something about Williams College students because then I could see firsthand how the statistical analysis we use in the classroom can be used and applied to real world situations that I am actually a part of (ex. does what building you study in at night affect GPA and questions like that).

column6:
To be honest, I got into it mostly for fun. Back in high school, I took pure math classes alongside mechanics and statistics — they always seemed to complement each other in a truck load of magnificent ways. I also worked on two data analysis projects from a CS perspective, where we had to handle outlier, erroneous data and calculate all sorts of things, like a Pearson's coefficient. I remember thinking, “WHA -- where did that formula even come from?” I want to have those "Aha" moments. I want to understand how statistical methods are derived — not just how to use them, but why and how they work. One thing that really intrigued me was the approximation from a normal distribution to a binomial one. Why do we do that? I wanted to dig into the reasoning behind those kinds of decisions.
Finally, I hope to major in Physics.
column7: 2 years ago, I saw a movie dataset on Kaggle that compiled information from cinemas using the "Rotten tomatoes" API. It included over a hundred film with details like release dates, user ratings, vote counts, popularity scores and not to mention - directors — all ripe for statistical analysis. What fascinated me was how you could visualize trends over time, like how certain genres gained popularity and who were the top 10 most popular directors of all time by ratings. It made me realize how statistics can uncover hidden patterns in something as everyday as the movies we watch.
column8: Anything that has interesting insights, except for college admissions.
column11: No, but I have taken other programming courses.
